text: Do not boast ⸤about tomorrow⸥,\f + \fr 27:1 \ft Literally “on the day of tomorrow” \f*
for you do not know what the day will bring.
May another praise you and not your own mouth,
a stranger and not your own lips.
Heavy \add is\add* a stone and weighty \add is\add* sand,
but \add the\add* provocation of a fool \add is\add* heavier than both of them.
Cruel \add is\add* wrath and overwhelming \add is\add* anger,
but who will stand before jealousy?
Better a rebuke that is open
than a love that is hidden.
The wounds of a friend mean well,
but the kisses of an enemy are profane.
An ⸤appetite⸥\f + \fr 27:7 \ft Literally “soul” \f* that is sated spurns honey,
but \add to\add* an ⸤appetite⸥\f + \fr 27:7 \ft Literally “soul” \f* that is ravenous, all bitterness \add is\add* sweet.
Like a bird that strays from its nest,
so is a man who strays from his place.
Perfume and incense will gladden a heart,
and the pleasantness of one’s friend \add is\add* ⸤personal advice⸥.\f + \fr 27:9 \ft Literally “because of advice of a person” \f*
As for your friend and a friend of your father, do not forsake \add them\add*,
and the house of your brother, do not enter on the day of your calamity.
Better is a close neighbor than a distant brother.
Be wise, my child, and make my heart glad,
and I will answer him who reproaches me \add with\add* a word.
\add When\add* the clever sees danger, he hides;
the simple go on \add and\add* suffer.
Take his garment, for he gives surety \add to\add* a stranger,
and to ⸤an adulteress⸥\f + \fr 27:13 \ft Literally “a foreign woman” \f*—\add so\add* take his pledge.
He who blesses his neighbor with a loud voice
early in the morning,
a curse will be reckoned to him.
Dripping constantly on a day of heavy rain
and a woman\f + \fr 27:15 \ft Or “wife” \f* of contention are alike.
\add In\add* restraining her, he restrains wind,\f + \fr 27:16 \ft Or “breath, or “spirit” \f*
and his right hand will grasp oil\f + \fr 27:16 \ft Or “fat” \f*.
\add As\add* iron sharpens\f + \fr 27:17 \ft Or “is united with” \f* iron,
so ⸤one man sharpens another⸥.\f + \fr 27:17 \ft Literally “a man sharpens \fq the \ft faces of his friend” \f*
He who tends a fig tree will eat its fruit,
and he who guards his master\f + \fr 27:18 \ft Or “lord” \f* will be honored.
As the waters \add reflect\add* ⸤face to face⸥,\f + \fr 27:19 \ft Literally “the faces to the faces” \f*
so the heart of a person \add reflects\add* the person.

Sheol\f + \fr 27:20 \ft A term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld \f* and Abaddon\f + \fr 27:20 \ft Poetic synonym for “Sheol.” Only mentioned in the \sc ot\sc* in relation to Sheol, the grave, or death. \f* will not be satisfied,
and the eyes of a person will not be satisfied \add either\add*.
A crucible \add is\add* for the silver, and a furnace for the gold,
but a man \add is tested by\add* the mouth of him who praises him.
If you crush a fool in the mortar with the pestle ⸤along with⸥\f + \fr 27:22 \ft Or “in the midst of” \f* the crushed grain,
it will not drive folly from upon him.
You will surely know the ⸤condition⸥\f + \fr 27:23 \ft Literally “faces” \f* of your flock;
your heart\f + \fr 27:23 \ft Or “mind” \f* attends to the herds.
For riches \add are\add* not forever,
nor a crown for generation \add after\add* generation.
When the grass is gone, then green growth will appear,
and the herbs of the mountains will be gathered.
Lambs \add will be\add* your clothing,
and goats the price of the field.
And \add there will be\add* enough goats’ milk for your food,
for \add the\add* food of your household and \add the\add* ⸤nourishment⸥\f + \fr 27:27 \ft Literally “life” \f* of your maidservants.
